Detailed Description

A closure object is a call to a function. It is also called task.

The closure is created to represent a computation. Using closure the users may split its works into subcomputation called closures. A closure has a runtime state that is inherited from Core::Condition which allows to defined five states, INIT, EXEC, STEAL, WAIT, and TERM. The state diagram is the following. Note that the state EXEC also represents closures that are ready and, at the end, terminated.

After initialization, a closure is in state INIT. If the closure is executed it pass to the states EXEC followed by TERM. If the closure is stolen then it pass to the states STEAL and then TERM. A closure may also pass to the state WAIT, in this case it should repass to the state EXEC or STEAL to be executed.

A closure object is initialized when pushed into its container. Base Closure cannot be pushed because it does not have fields to be insert in container. See Closure which is the standard closure in Kaapi that can be pushed into stack frame container.

void RFO::BaseClosure::run ( Core::Thread *  thread  )  [inline]

Call run on the closure object. This method allows to call the runfunction on a closure object. It differs from Thread::run() that tests an suspend thread in case of stolen closure.
